note.p: Thomas Overton Moore was governor of Louisiana during most of the Civil War.

Born on April 10, 1804, in Sampson County, North Carolina, Moore moved to Louisiana at the age of 25 to manage his uncle’s cotton plantation. He eventually purchased his own property and established a financially successful plantation. By the late 1840s he was involved in politics, winning a seat in the Louisiana House of Representatives in 1848 and the state’s Senate in 1856. He served as chairman of the state’s Education Committee and helped establish Louisiana State Seminary (modern-day Louisiana State University), with future Union general William Tecumseh Sherman as the school’s first superintendent.

In 1859 Moore won election as Louisiana’s governor, taking office in January 1860. As governor, he spoke strongly against northern anti-slavery sentiments and vehemently opposed Abraham Lincoln’s election to the presidency in November 1860. In January 1861, Moore ordered the state’s militia to seize U.S. military posts within the Louisiana, before state formally declared its secession from the Union. After Louisiana joined the Confederacy in March 1861, Moore called for Confederate support to defend New Orleans. As he feared, Union naval and ground forces advanced against the port city early in the war, securing in April 1862, and forcing the state’s government to move out of Baton Rouge for central Louisiana.

Moore remained governor until 1864, most of his time in office seeing Union forces hold key parts of Louisiana. He returned to his plantation but was forced to leave when Union soldiers under General Nathaniel P. Banks raided his property during the Red River Campaign in the spring of 1864. Moore fled to Mexico and then Cuba rather than surrender to Union forces in 1865. From Havana, he applied to President Andrew Johnson for a pardon—the request being delivered by General William Tecumseh Sherman personally. Johnson pardoned Moore in 1867, and Moore returned to Louisiana. He regained his lost property, again aided by Sherman, but never returned to political office.
Moore was married to Bethiah Johnston Leonard and had five children. He died on June 25, 1876, near Alexandria, Louisiana. He is buried at Mount Olivet Cemetery in Pineville, Louisiana.

Located in Orleans Parish, New Orleans was founded in 1718. It became the capital of French Louisiana in 1722 and continued as the capital when Louisiana achieved statehood on April 30, 1812. It became part of Orleans County (now extinct) on the same day. In 1849 it was replaced by Baton Rouge as the state capital, although it temporarily served as the capital again from 1865 until 1880. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

note.p: Located in East Baton Rouge Parish, Baton Rouge was founded as early as 1699 and serves as the parish seat. Baton Rouge became the capital of Louisiana in 1846. (Wikipedia; Britannica)

The first newspaper published in Louisiana was the Moniteur de la Louisiana, a French-language publication started during French control of the territory. The first English-language newspaper in Louisiana, the Union: New Orleans Advertiser and Price Current, opened shortly after the United States obtained the territory from France with the Louisiana Purchase nine years later, in 1803. Over the next few decades, newspaper companies (in French and English) opened as communities grew and the demand for information increased. Publishing resources (like paper and print presses) became more available aiding in the news media boom. By the mid-nineteenth century, most Louisiana towns or counties had a local newspaper, published daily or weekly. Major cities typically had more than one newspaper, often published by competing political parties. Most newspapers went out of business after only a few years; however, a few continued in print for decades, including the Baton Rouge Gazette (1819–1856), Le Meschacébé (1853–1942), and The Donaldsonville Chief which began in 1871 and is still in publication. Overall, more than one hundred different publishers started daily or weekly newspapers in Louisiana during the nineteenth century. (Tim Hughes, “First newspapers in Louisiana…,” History’s Newsstand Blog; Library of Congress)

Operating at the state level, the Louisiana State Executive Department was established by Article 3 of the Louisiana Constitution in 1812 and serves as part of the executive branch of the Louisiana state government. It is led by the Louisiana State Governor, who directly presides over the Cabinet. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Louisiana Secretary of State is an elected official who serves a four-year term and is responsible for overseeing state election laws and government records. (Wikipedia)

The term "fugitive from justice" is defined broadly and covers a multiplicity of experiences under U.S. law, but refers most often to "a person who is fleeing from custody, whether it be from jail, a government arrest, government or non-government questioning, vigilante violence, or outraged private individuals" (Wikipedia). Slightly different than the above definition, a fugitive from justice may also be defined as "a person formally charged with a crime or a convicted criminal whose punishment has not yet been determined or fully served who is currently beyond the custody or control" of the party, be it local, national, or international, interested in their arrest (Wikipedia). In the nineteenth-century United States, fugitive status varied widely based on race. Many white people considered "fugitives from justice" were most often the latter definition, being those charged with or convicted of crimes who then fled across other state lines to try and evade punishment or trial. However, throughout American history up to Emancipation, fugitive status was given to escaped enslaved African Americans under the Fugitive Slave Laws of 1793 and later 1850. These laws also required anyone in the nation to apprehend self-emancipated enslaved people and return them to their owners. The term "fugitives from justice" therefore became another legal mechanism by which enslavers sought to control the movements and freedoms of the enslaved, while contributing heavily to the increasing sectionalism that would lead to the American Civil War (Britannica). To learn more about enslaved people who emancipations themselves and were labeled fugitives, see the "Emancipation and self-emancipation" subject tag under Events.

div.p: EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT,
State of [image: eagle and balances] Louisiana.
To the Executive Authority of the State of Mississippi

Whereas, it appears by the annexed document, which is hereby certified to be authentic, that Jose Armoras y Rubio and Juan Montoro stands charged with the crime of obtaining goods under false pretences committed in the State of Louisiana: And information having been received that the said Jose Armoras y Rubio & Juan Montoro have fled from Justice and taken refuge in the state of Mississippi

Therefore, I Thomas O. Moore—Governor of the State of Louisiana, have thought proper, in pursuance of the provisions of the Constitution and Laws of the United States, to demand the ^arrest &^ surrender of the said Jose Armoras y Rubio & Juan Montoro as fugitives from Justice, and that they be delivered to Simon Boulosa who is hereby appointed Agent on the part of the State of Louisiana to receive
[seal]

Given under my hand and the Seal of the State, at the City of Baton Rouge this Eleventh—day of September in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and fiftysixty-one and of the Independence of the United States of America, the [gap]

P D Hardy
DAILY ADVOCATE PRINT, Baton Rouge,
[unclear]HE STATE OF LOUISIANA.

THE STATE
VS.
Jose Armoras y Rubio
&
Juan Montoro

STATE WITNESSES.
Antonio Costa
No 16 Custom House streets
PERSONALLY came and appeared before me, LOUIS GASTINEL, Recorder of the Second District, of the City of New Orleans, duly commissioned and sworn as Justice of the Peace,[gap]
Antonio Costa

Who being duly sworn, declares that he is a commissioned merchant on C. House No 16 & states that about ten days ago, two individuals named Jose Armoras y Rubio and Juan Montoro came to deponent's office aforesaid & obtained from deponent a lot of Havana Tobacco of the value of seven Hundred dollars, which deponent sold & delivered to them for cash, that is upon the representation that Jose Armoras y Rubio made to deponent that the said Jose Armoras y Rubio had a certain quantity of spanish dobloons deposited @ Fajo & Burnaso merchants @ old Levee st between Urselines & Hospital streets, and that he José Armoras y Rubio or Fajo & Burnaso would calls immediately @ deponents to settle & pay said amount of seven Hundred dollars. That on the same day the said José Armoras y Rubio and Juan Montoro, did sale for cash to a certain individual whose name is unknown to deponent the said lot of Havana Tobacco and have Kept the produce of said sale for their own use & have absconded from this city without settling or paying to deponent the said sum of seven Hundred dollars, Deponent further states that he apply to Fajo & Brunaso & was informed by said firm that there was (no dobloons or money whatsoever) deposited in their House for a/c of José Armoras y Rubio. Deponent therefore charges the said José Armoras y Rubio and Juan Montoro of obtaining goods under false pretences & prays that they be arrested & dealt with according to law.
Sworn to & subscribed before me. this 11th day of September 1861.

(signed Louis Gastinel
Recorder 2ndDt.
"Signed
Anto Costa

I do hereby certify the above to be a true & correct copy.
N. Orleans September 11th,, 1861.

[?]
Clerk Recorder 2nd Dt.

STATE OF LOUISIANA.
VS.
Jose Armoros y Rubio
&
Juan Montoro
obtaining goods under false pretences
11th,, September 1861.
Ant. Costa

a true & correct copy
N. Orleans 11th,, September 1861.
[?]
Clerk's Recorder 2nd Dt

[unclear]HE STATE OF LOUISIANA,
CITY OF NEW ORLEANS.
RECORDER'S OFFICE, SECOND DISTRICT.
WARRRANT.
To the CHIEF OF POLICE, or any of the Policemen of the City of New Orleans,
GREETING:

WHEREAS, complaint has been made on the oath of Ant Costa before me, Louis Gastinel, Recorder of the Second District of the City aforesaid, that José Armoros y Rubio & Juan Montoro Stands charged with obtaining goods under false pretences

You are hereby commanded to take the body^ies^ of the said Jose Armoros y Rubio & Juan Montoro and bring them with this Warrant before me, to answer to the complaint, and should they not be found or seen within three days from the date hereof, you will not fail to return immediately this warrant, with what you have done endorsed thereon.
NEW ORLEANS, this 11th,, day of September 1861

L. Gastinel
Recorder of the Second District of the City of New Orleans.
